item.title: Article: 5 ways to boost your sales
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
Many people ask me how to increase sales and, at a higher level, there are 5 main areas to work on:

Increase the quantity of sales leads

It may be obvious that more sales leads will lead to more sales. What is less obvious is where the sales leads come from. The best and easiest source of sales is from existing clients where you already have a strong relationship.  For example, you could:
  • Sell them more of the same
  • Sell them a premium version of what they are already buying
  • Selling them something extra
  • Extend  your reach within the account
  • Get them to make a referral

Increase the quality of sales leads

Rather than increase the quantity of the sales lead, you could work on increasing the quality of sales lead so that you are only selling to people who appreciate what you have to offer and your key point of difference. For most businesses, this means working on their core sales messaging and getting better at targeting their marketing communications.

Work on your selling skill

In addition to increasing the quality and quantity of sales leads, you can get better at closing the sale so that more of your sales opportunities are converted into cash in the bank. If you are already confident with the basics, then getting a sales coach or mentor could help you to find those small changes that make a big difference.

Increase the sales amount

You can increase the sales amount by either increasing the quantity purchased and/or or increasing the price. Now that you have improved your selling skills you will know how to minimise price objections and sell based on value!

Increase the speed of the sale

Sales are not only impacted by the quantity of sales leads generated and the rate at which they are converted into sales. They are also affected by the speed at which they are converted into sales. For example, if it normally takes 3 months to close a sale and you reduce that time by a month then your sales will get a boost from the sales coming through the pipeline quicker.

item.title: Article: Sales insights that make selling easier
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
If, like me,  you are an accidental sales person then selling can at first seem like a dark art. However, once you understand some fundamental insights about human nature then it all starts to get a lot clearer and selling gets much easier. Here are some of the top insights that made a difference for me:

People buy for their own reasons

To be successful in sales we need to change the focus from what we are selling onto our target audience and finding reasons for them to want to buy.

People buy from people they know like and trust

People do not trust pushy sales people and so if we are too pushy then our prospects are unlikely to trust us. Consultative selling is a method of selling that, when done properly, builds trust.

People like people like themselves

Rather than learning pushy sales techniques we should be learning how to develop relationships with a wider range of people.

People make their buying decisions based on emotion

All human behaviour is driven by motivation. Understanding why our clients buy from us makes it easier to make our products and services sound more attractive.

People will always find the money to buy what they want

If we are selling to the right people then there is no reason to give in on price to win the sale. Indeed, there could even be the scope to increase prices.

item.title: Article: How to avoid the six costly mistakes business owners make when hiring sales people
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
Hiring a good sales person can be one of the best things you do for your business but equally it can turn into an expensive nightmare. Here are some costly mistakes to avoid:

Mistake # 1 - Assuming all sales people are the same

There are more than 7 different styles of selling. In addition, certain sales people have areas of strength and weakness. For example, some are great at generating sales leads but not so good at closing the sale (and visa versa). Just like any other job, you need to understand the specific skills required for the sales role and then seek to match applicants skills to those required. For example, if you are looking for someone to cold call then you need to seeking people who can demonstrate  this skill.

Mistake # 2 - Recruiting a sales person to figure things out

Part of the problem is that many business owners do not understand and feel in control of their sales and so they think getting a good sales person will help them figure things out. They hope it will free up more of their time to focus on running the business and doing what they are best at. In such a case, it would be cheaper and quicker to engage experts to gain that clarity before hiring the sales person.

Mistake # 3 - Hiring commission-only sales people

Good commission-only sales people, often called sales agents, are a special breed and you do need to understand their psychology to attract and keep them. The good ones like things that are very simple to sell and whether they get paid quickly. Also, it is rare that you will find one that will commit to only selling for you. In my experience, commission-only sales people who take on products with longer sales cycles where they have to wait a long time to get paid are either naive or desperate. Either way, you risk wasting time and energy if you try and manage then like normal sales people.

Mistake # 4 - Relying on interviewing

The problem with the interview process is that there are some questions that are very difficult to ask such as “Are you being honest when you say you love cold calling?” You also have the fact that even poor sales people are good at telling you what you want to hear. There are many sales assessments out there and most will give you an idea of whether someone can sell or not. The one I use is much more sophisticated and tells me not only if they can sell but whether they will sell in a specific sales job. There is a cost attached to these assessments but when you know how easy it is to make an expensive hiring mistake they become essential. My advice is to research sales assessments thoroughly first before you decide which one to use. Ask to see samples and have the results explained to you.

Mistake # 5 - Relying on a recruitment agency

As you can see, hiring a sales person can be a risky business so perhaps it is worth going to the expense of using a specialist recruitment consultancy to hire someone. Unfortunately recruitment consultants are little better at predicting whether a sales person will be successful in a specific sales role.  Still expect to need to run a sales assessment, even if you use a specialise sales recruitment agency.

Mistake # 6 - Hiring a friend of a friend

Many smaller businesses seek to save on the cost of recruitment agencies by telling people in their network about their sales job and asking for recommendations. Whilst this is not a mistake in itself, doing so without a process that includes a sales assessment turns this into a high risk approach. This is because there is often some kind of obligation towards the friend and, in my experience the business owner tends to overlook some glaringly obvious signs. For example, I was recently asked to help with finding the ideal sales person and then the business owner came up with “the perfect sales person” through a recommendation of a friend. All the signs were this person was low on commitment but they were ignored. It took a sales assessment to make that clear to the person and thankfully he avoided making a costly mistake. If you want to reduce costs then there are specialist web recruitment agencies which just do the online advertising. You pay them to place a job advert online and then they collect in the resumes and forward them to you to do the initial screening. Some will do this initial screening for you and my experience is that this produces just as good results as many recruitment agencies.

item.title: Expert interview: Generating sales leads from exhibitions
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
Exhibitions can be a good source of sales leads if you approach them in the right way. It's a great way to reach and start a conversation with people who are actively looking for the products and services you are offering. Getting exhibitions right could lead to a significant boost in sales. Get them wrong and it could end up being an waste of time and money. In this interview, BizClub's Richard White quizzes small business marketing expert Alan Rae about what it takes to maximise the business generated from exhibitions. Alan gives a lot of tips inclding some lower cost options for exhibiting your business. In particular he covers:
  • What you MUST do prior to the exhibition
  • How to do so that you maximise the sales leads generated from your investment in an exhibition stand.
  • How to ensure your leads turn into sales once the exhibition is over!
If you get a chance then take notes. Although it is delivered in an easy to digest fashion it is packed with practical ideas. You may want to listen to this more than once.     [audio mp3="http://hzhapr15a.dmclub.net/salesandmarketing/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2015/03/alanraeexhibitions4.mp3"][/audio] To download - right click here as select 'Save As'

Alan Rae is a business adviser and coach focusing on helping growing companies overcome marketing and communication issues having been an owner manager of IT related companies since 1981. Alan is an avid researcher and in addition to being the author of many books, teaches courses in Entrepreneurial Marketing at business schools in the UK and in France. item.title: Expert interview: Creating a one-page marketing plan
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
A marketing planning is an essential business document that ensures that we focus our marketing budget in the areas that will maximise the sales leads generated. Yet few business owners know how to put together a marketing plan that gets results. In this recording BizClub's Richard White interviews straight talking small business marketing expert Rod Sloane. Rod explains what a marketing plan is and what it is not. Specifically, Rod covers:
  • Why a marketing plan is important
  • The essential elements of an effective marketing plan
  • How to turn your marketing plan into an action plan
  • How to keep your marketing plan to one page.
In his typically entertaining no-nonsense  style, Rod guides us through how to write a marketing plan and how then to turn the marketing plan into a 'to do' list for our lead generation activity. item.title: Expert interview: Marketing on a shoe string
item.dc:creator: rwhite
item.content:encoded:
Marketing can seem like a bottomless pit with no shortage of choices to spend our modest marketing budgets. Indeed, there is so much choice that many small businesses end up doing no marketing at all. In this inspiring interview, marketing expert Rosie Hatton talks to BizClub's Richard White about the many effective marketing strategies that are either low-cost or no-cost. Rosie's company Hatton Digital specialises in helping clients with a limited marketing budget to maximise the sales impact of their marketing spend. He advice is based on real world experience at the sharp end. This is an excellent resource for people new to marketing. Rosie gives a nice and simple definition of marketing and outlines where businesses typically waste money. Rosie also gives many simple to follow tips for marketing to support lead generation on a shoestring budget.
